SEARCH
Package org.loudouncodes.combinatorics

Class Permutations

java.lang.Object
org.loudouncodes.combinatorics.Permutations
All Implemented Interfaces:
Iterable<int[]>
public class Permutations extends Object implements Iterable<int[]>
Generates ordered k-permutations (k-tuples without repetition) drawn from the integer domain {0, 1, ..., n-1} and exposes them via Java's enhanced for loop by implementing Iterable<int[]>.

What is a k-permutation?

A k-permutation of n distinct items is an ordered selection of k different elements, no repeats allowed. For example, with n = 4 and k = 2, valid tuples include [0,1], [1,0], [2,3], etc. The total count is nPk = n! / (n-k)!.

Order of generation (lexicographic over the k-length array)

Tuples are produced in lexicographic order with respect to their array entries. Example: 


 new Permutations(2, 3)  // n = 3, k = 2
 -> [0,1], [0,2], [1,0], [1,2], [2,0], [2,1]

Algorithm (lexicographic successor on k-length tuples)

Maintain the current tuple p[0..k-1]. To advance to the next tuple:

  1. Scan positions from right to left (i = k-1 down to 0).
  2. For the first position i that can be increased, choose the smallest value cand > p[i] that is not already used in the prefix p[0..i-1].
  3. Set p[i] = cand, then rebuild the suffix p[i+1..k-1] with the smallest unused values in ascending order.
  4. If no position can be increased, we are past the final tuple.

This is analogous to an odometer that carries left, except that each position must be a value not used earlier in the tuple; the suffix is always reset to its minimal lexicographic configuration consistent with the prefix.

Correctness intuition

  • Exhaustiveness: Starting at [0,1,...,k-1] and repeatedly applying the successor rule reaches every legal k-tuple exactly once.
  • No duplicates: The algorithm never reuses a value within a tuple and never revisits an already-emitted tuple; the successor is deterministic and strictly increases lexicographically until exhaustion.
  • Ordering: We increase the rightmost position that can be increased and then minimize the suffix, which yields standard lexicographic order over the k-length arrays.

Complexity

  • Time per tuple: O(n) worst case (we may scan a boolean "used" array and rebuild the suffix).
  • Total tuples: nPk = n! / (n-k)! â€” available via size().
  • Space: O(k) for the current tuple, plus O(n) for a transient "used" bitmap inside the successor step.

Edge cases

  • k == 0: a single empty array [] is emitted.
  • k == n: emits all n! permutations in lexicographic order.
  • Invalid inputs (negative, or k > n) throw IllegalArgumentException.

Example


 Permutations perms = new Permutations(3, 5);
 System.out.println("Total: " + perms.size()); // prints nPk
 for (int[] p : perms) {
     System.out.printf("[%d, %d, %d]%n", p[0], p[1], p[2]);
 }

Implementation note: Each Iterator.next() returns a defensive copy of the internal array. This protects the iterator's state from external mutation.

Since:
0.1.0

  • Constructor Details

    • Permutations

      public Permutations(int k, int n)
      Constructs a generator of ordered k-permutations from {0..n-1}.
      Parameters:
      k - length of each tuple (must satisfy 0 <= k <= n)
      n - size of the ground set (n >= 0)
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if k < 0, n < 0, or k > n

  • Method Details

    • size

      public long size()
      Returns the total number of ordered k-permutations (falling factorial nPk).

      Note: this uses long and will overflow for large inputs. For classroom-scale inputs (e.g., n <= 20) it is typically fine. For arbitrary precision, provide a BigInteger variant.

      Returns:
      nPk as a long

    • iterator

      public Iterator<int[]> iterator()
      Returns a fresh iterator positioned at the first tuple [0,1,...,k-1] (or the empty array if k == 0).
      Specified by:
      iterator in interface Iterable<int[]>
      Returns:
      iterator over lexicographically ordered k-permutations

    • main

      public static void main(String[] args)
      Small demo for quick sanity checks. Prints all k-permutations for k = 3, n = 5. This is not used by the library and may be removed in production builds.
      Parameters:
      args - ignored
